_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Traditions is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. The company accidental release prevention program covers design, installation, operations, maintenance and training. 



The facility receives and stores frozen food, cooks food, and packages and freezes food trays for shipment to customers. Anhydrous ammonia, which is used as a refrigerant, is the only substance regulated by the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule and the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. The maximum inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 18,000 pounds.



The ammonia refrigeration facility is designed and operated in accordance with accepted engineering and industrial codes and standards. Traditions retains information that describes the chemical hazards, operating procedures and equipment design associated with ammonia refrigeration. The company diligently identifies process hazards and controls them efficiently. For instance, Traditions uses written operating procedures for process safety that address several modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround. This information is regularly reviewed and made readily accessible to process operators as well as to maintenance and support personnel involved in the ammonia refrigeration process.



Traditions trains employees who will operate the ammonia refrigeration process to ensure they are competent. Refresher training is provided as needed buy at least every three years.



The company documents maintenance inspection of equipment in ammonia service to ensure proper and safe operations. Regularly inspected process equipment includes, among others, pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, process controls and pumps. Only qualified personnel perform maintenance on the ammonia refrigeration system. Furthermore, maintenance personnel are given ammonia safety training. Ammonia refriger

ation equipment deficiencies identified by maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Change to the system or equipment components is managed in accordance with written procedure. Employees who would be affected by a modification in the ammonia refrigeration system are promptly made aware of the changes. Pre-startup safety reviews will be used to validate construction, process equipment installation, and operation and maintenance procedures prior to placing new or modified equipment into ammonia service.



Traditions audits itself to insure that provisions of the RMP rule and PSM standard are fully implemented. These audits are conducted at least every three years and corrective measures are undertaken promptly.



Although Traditions has not experienced a significant release of ammonia from the system the company will promptly investigate incidents that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia. The goal of such investigation is to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions necessary to prevent the situation from recurrence.



The company conducts process safety management and accident prevention as a team effort. System operation and maintenance employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend process safety and procedural improvements. Additionally, the affected employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule and PSM standard, including information resulting from process hazard analyses. Traditions has an excellent record of operating without an accidental release. If fact, an accidental release has never occurred.



From time to time the company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance or construction or renovation activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of his safety perofrmance is completed. Traditions informs cont

ractors of potential ammonia and other pertinent hazards related to the contractor's work and the company's processes. Contractors are also informed of procedures that must be followed for emergency response in the event of an accidently release of anhydrous ammonia.



The emergency plan is being coordinated with the Pearl Fire Department and the Rankin County Emergency Planning Committee. Four wind socks are available to assist evacuees and emergency responders in determining upwind and downwind directions.
